A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
Rian Johnson (Looper) takes over from JJ Abrams in the director's chair to deliver the 2nd installment in this new Star Wars trilogy.

Carrying on where The Force Awakens left off\, we see the Resistance led my General Leia Organa (Carrie Fisher in her final role before passing away) pursued by the heavily manned First Order whilst new character from the previous film\, Rey (Daisy Ridley) tracks down Jedi master in hiding\, Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill) and discovers more about why the Force and what drove Luke to seek solace on the planet Ahch-To.

Adam Driver returns as Kylo Ren\, apprentice to Supreme Leader Snoke (Andy Serkis) and it's his relationship with Rey and Luke which provides the film with it's most interesting themes and concepts\, as the lines between light and dark become blurred.

Early in the film\, we are introduced to new character Rose (played by Kelly Marie Tran) who is involved in a subplot with Finn (John Boyega) as they track down a codebreaker to aid the Rebellion.  Some feel that this subplot is unnecessary and slows the film down\, however\, I felt that it served to introduced themes unseen in Star Wars before.

Carrie Fisher\, Mark Hamill\, and Adam Driver all deliver excellent performances and Daisy Ridley and Oscar Isaac (returning as Poe Dameron) continue to impress.

There are some unexpected returning characters which I won't spoil\, but there is a moment that did make me cry and want to punch the air at the same time.  As punching the air is not a done thing in the cinema I settled for just crying instead.

This film has divided fans\, some feeling that it doesn't meet their high expectations and it is by no means perfect but it is the most nuanced Star Wars film to date and tries to take the saga in a new direction.
